details.title: Longitudinal Models for Non-Stationary Exponential Data
details.standardTitle: Longitudinal Models for Non-Stationary Exponential Data

p: M. Tariqul Hasan earned his B.Sc. degree in Statistics from Dhaka University, Bangladesh in 1995; and M.Sc., and Ph.D. degrees in Statistics from Memorial University of Newfoundland, Canada in 2001, and 2005 respectively. He is currently an Assistant Professor in the Department of Mathematics and Statistics, University of New Brunswick, Fredericton, NB, Canada. His research interests are in the areas of longitudinal data analysis, survival analysis, and generalized linear and non-linear mixed models.

authors.affiliation: Dept. of Math. & Stat., Univ. of New Brunswick, Fredericton, NB
authors.name: M. Tariqul Hasan

details.abstract: In many manufacturing studies, longitudinal failure time data comprise repeated exponential responses, and a set of multi-dimensional covariates for a large number of independent components or objects. When the covariates collected along with exponential failure times are time dependent, the responses of an object exhibit non-stationary correlations. We examine the effects of the covariates by taking this non-stationary correlation structure into account. First, we develop Gaussian type non-stationary AR(1), MA(1), and exchangeable correlation structures for the repeated exponential failure times; and then exploit the suitable auto-correlation structure to obtain consistent, efficient estimates for the effects of the covariates by using a generalized quasi-likelihood (GQL) estimating equation approach. The finite sample estimation performance of the GQL approach is examined through a simulation study.

context.text: For the longitudinal set up, [8] proposed modeling as well as inferential techniques under binary and/or count data.
To overcome this problem, [8] proposed a generalized quasi-likelihood (GQL)-based estimation procedure for binary and/or count data.
In this paper, we apply the techniques suggested in [8] to the analysis of exponential data.
Following [7], [8] has modeled the longitudinal correlations for discrete random variables such as Poisson and binary longitudinal response variables.

Following [8], the GQL estimating equation can be written as For known \$\rho=(\rho_{1},\rho_{2},\ldots,\rho_{n-1})^{\prime}\$, the solution of \${\mmb \beta}\$ from (11) is achieved by using the well-known Gauss-Newton iteration procedure, which can be written as where \$[.]_{(r)}\$ denotes that the expression within the square brackets is evaluated at \$\mathhat{\mmb \beta}_{\rm GQL}(r)\$, the values of \$\mathhat{\mmb \beta}_{\rm GQL}\$ at the \$r\$th iteration.

Following [8], the lag \$l\$ correlation \$\rho_{l}\$ may be consistently estimated by using the method of moments, and denoted by \$\mathhat{\rho}_{(M)l}\$, which has the form given by where with \$t_{ki}\$ being the failure time of the \$k\$th individual at the \$i\$th occasion.
